data.question: What is the purpose of using metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) in the stabilization of gold(III) catalysts?
data.answer: The purpose of using MOFs in the stabilization of gold(III) catalysts is to prevent a unimolecular decomposition pathway and enable recyclability of the catalyst.

data.question: What are the two MOFs mentioned in the text for stabilizing gold(III) catalysts?
data.answer: The two MOFs mentioned are IRMOF-10 and bio-MOF-100.

data.question: True or False: The homogeneous gold(III) catalyst is prone to decomposition in solution.
What is the role of 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene in the decomposition experiments of gold(III) complexes?
data.answer: 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene acts as a trap for cationic gold(I) species in the decomposition experiments.

data.question: What method is used to analyze the single crystal structure of IPrAu(III)(H2BPDC)Cl?
data.answer: Single crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) analysis is used.

data.question: True or False: The occupancy of gold in IPrAu(III)Cl-bio-MOF-100 after chloride abstraction remains unchanged.
What is the significance of the PXRD patterns shown in the supplemental figures?
data.answer: The PXRD patterns confirm the crystallinity and phase purity of the MOF samples before and after catalysis.

data.question: How is the decomposition of homogeneous gold(III) complexes compared to their MOF analogs?
data.answer: Homogeneous gold(III) complexes show significant decomposition, whereas their MOF analogs do not show decomposition under similar conditions.

data.question: True or False: The catalysis observed with IPrAu(III)SbF6-IRMOF-10 occurs within the pores of the framework.
What is the effect of substrate size on the catalysis with IPrAu(III)SbF6-IRMOF-10?
data.answer: An increase in substrate size leads to a decrease in reactivity, indicating that catalysis occurs within the pores of the framework.
